reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Emergency Nutrition Response for the displaced population in Oromia (East and West Wollega), Benishangul Gumuz (Kamashi and Assosa Zones and Somali (Dawa Zone) of Ethiopia

description.narrative:
Ethiopia continues to face inter-communal conflicts with large-scale displacement on the rise. In the most recent wave of conflict in Benishangul and Oromia regions, it is estimated that at least 240,000 people were displaced inside Benishangul Gumuz region (15,000 in Oda and 42,000 in Kamashi zones) and across the border in Oromia region (101,000 in East Wollega and 81,000 in West Wollega). Meanwhile, there has been a significant influx of ethnic Amharas who were displaced within Benishangul-Gumuz region (Kamashi zone) as a result of the conflict in Western Oromia and Benishangul-Gumuz regions as well as from other regions. Prior to the escalation of inter-communal violence and displacements in 2018, there were at least 1,073,764 people displaced - mainly due to violence between the Oromos and Somalis over territory and access to resources since September 2017. An estimated 500,000 IDP reside in Somali Region due to conflict and the effect of protracted drought. They remain highly vulnerable and in need of a complete response and recovery package of interventions.
The recently displaced population is settled in camps, with some people staying with members of the host communities. In this situation, children and PLW form one of the most vulnerable groups, as they often have limited or no access to nutritious foods, lack appropriate health care, and subsequently face increasing risks of malnutrition and ill health. Furthermore, in the western part of Oromia region, particularly East and West Wollega zones and Benishangul Gumuz region, there is very little or no experience in emergency response. This project will address this gap in expertise.
To address these issues, UNICEF proposes to procure and distribute BP5, energy-dense biscuits designed for emergency settings to a total of 53,737 people (38,030 children age 6-59 months and 15,707 PLWs) in Oromia, Benishangul Gumuz and Somali regions (14 days’ ration). The project will also support the government system to better monitor and coordinate the emergency nutrition response and will support the sectors/cluster to enhance community mobilization and outreach.
